title: 1 Samuel Chapter 22 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Samuel chapter 22 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 22 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Samuel Chapter 22.

questions.question: Where did David escape to according to 1 Samuel 22:1?
options: The cave Adullam
The forest of Hareth
Mizpeh of Moab
Gibeah
questions.correctAnswer: The cave Adullam
questions.explanation: David departed and escaped to the cave Adullam as stated in 1 Samuel 22:1.

questions.question: Who gathered themselves to David when he was at the cave Adullam?
options: Those in distress, debt, and discontent
Saul's servants
The priests of Nob
The Benjamites
questions.correctAnswer: Those in distress, debt, and discontent
questions.explanation: Verse 2 states that everyone in distress, debt, and discontent gathered to David.

questions.question: To whom did David ask to let his father and mother stay in Mizpeh of Moab?
options: The king of Moab
The prophet Gad
The king of Israel
The Edomite Doeg
questions.correctAnswer: The king of Moab
questions.explanation: David spoke to the king of Moab asking him to let his parents stay with him (verse 3).

questions.question: Where did the prophet Gad tell David to go instead of staying in the hold?
options: The land of Judah
The cave Adullam
Gibeah
Nob
questions.correctAnswer: The land of Judah
questions.explanation: Gad instructed David to depart the hold and go to the land of Judah (verse 5).

questions.question: What weapon did Saul hold while abiding under a tree in Ramah?
options: His spear
A sword
A bow
A staff
questions.correctAnswer: His spear
questions.explanation: Verse 6 describes Saul abiding under a tree with his spear in his hand.

questions.question: Who was accused by Saul of conspiring against him with David?
options: The Benjamites
The priests of Nob
The Edomites
The Moabites
questions.correctAnswer: The Benjamites
questions.explanation: Saul addressed his servants, the Benjamites, accusing them of conspiring with David (verse 7).

questions.question: Who reported to Saul that David had visited Ahimelech the priest at Nob?
options: Doeg the Edomite
Abiathar
The prophet Gad
One of Saul's servants
questions.correctAnswer: Doeg the Edomite
questions.explanation: Doeg told Saul that he saw David coming to Nob to Ahimelech (verse 9).

questions.question: What did Ahimelech give David besides victuals?
options: The sword of Goliath
A spear
A shield
A bow and arrows
questions.correctAnswer: The sword of Goliath
questions.explanation: Ahimelech gave David victuals and the sword of Goliath (verse 10).

questions.question: What was Saul's punishment decree for Ahimelech and his father's house?
options: They shall surely die
They shall be imprisoned
They shall be exiled
They shall be forgiven
questions.correctAnswer: They shall surely die
questions.explanation: Saul declared that Ahimelech and all his father's house should surely die (verse 16).

questions.question: Who actually killed the priests of the LORD at Nob?
options: Doeg the Edomite
Saul's footmen
David
The Benjamites
questions.correctAnswer: Doeg the Edomite
questions.explanation: Saul's servants refused, so Doeg was ordered and he killed the priests (verse 18).

questions.question: Who escaped the massacre at Nob and fled to David?
options: Abiathar, son of Ahimelech
Doeg the Edomite
Gad the prophet
Ahitub
questions.correctAnswer: Abiathar, son of Ahimelech
questions.explanation: Abiathar escaped the killing and fled to David (verse 20).

questions.question: True or False: David told Abiathar to fear because he would be safe with him.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: David assured Abiathar not to fear and that he would be safe with him (verse 23).

questions.question: True or False: Saul's servants willingly killed the priests of the LORD at his command.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Saul's servants refused to kill the priests, so Doeg did it instead (verse 17-18).

questions.question: True or False: David went to Mizpeh of Moab to seek refuge for his parents.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: David asked the king of Moab to take care of his father and mother (verse 3).

questions.question: Complete this verse from 1 Samuel 22:14: 'And who is so ______ among all thy servants as David, which is the king's son in law...'
options: faithful
strong
wise
rich
questions.correctAnswer: faithful
questions.explanation: Ahimelech answered that David was the most faithful among all the king's servants (verse 14).

medium.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 22 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Samuel Chapter 22 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A believer is feeling isolated and discouraged, feeling like an outcast. Based on 1 Samuel 22, what biblical truth would encourage them about fellowship and support?
options: David gathered those in distress and discontented to him, forming a supportive community.
David avoided all people to focus only on God in solitude.
David immediately sought revenge on those who opposed him.
David abandoned his family and friends to survive alone.
questions.correctAnswer: David gathered those in distress and discontented to him, forming a supportive community.
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:1-2 shows David gathering his family and others who were in distress or discontented, demonstrating the importance of fellowship and mutual support during trials.

questions.question: How does David's request to the king of Moab about his parents teach us about honoring family during difficult times?
options: David asked the king of Moab to take care of his parents until he knew God's plan.
David sent his parents away without concern for their safety.
David left his parents behind without informing anyone.
David asked the king to send his parents away from Moab.
questions.correctAnswer: David asked the king of Moab to take care of his parents until he knew God's plan.
questions.explanation: In 1 Samuel 22:3-4, David honors his parents by ensuring their safety and care, showing the biblical value of honoring and protecting family even in hardship.

questions.question: What does the prophet Gad's instruction to David teach about obedience in times of uncertainty?
options: David was told to leave the hold and go to Judah as an act of obedience to God's guidance.
David was told to remain in the hold without moving.
David was instructed to confront Saul immediately.
David was told to go into exile in a foreign land.
questions.correctAnswer: David was told to leave the hold and go to Judah as an act of obedience to God's guidance.
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:5 shows Gad instructing David to obey God's direction and move, highlighting the importance of trusting and obeying God's leading even when the future is uncertain.

questions.question: How does Saul's reaction to the news about David illustrate the dangers of distrust and suspicion in leadership?
options: Saul accused his own servants of conspiring and showed suspicion without seeking truth.
Saul trusted his servants and sought peaceful resolution.
Saul ignored the news about David entirely.
Saul immediately repented and reconciled with David.
questions.correctAnswer: Saul accused his own servants of conspiring and showed suspicion without seeking truth.
questions.explanation: Verses 7-8 show Saul's distrust and suspicion toward his servants and David, warning about the destructive effects of mistrust and paranoia in leadership and relationships.

questions.question: What lesson about integrity and faithfulness can we learn from Ahimelech's defense before Saul?
options: Ahimelech testified to David's faithfulness and his own innocence in the matter.
Ahimelech confessed to conspiring against Saul.
Ahimelech refused to answer Saul's questions.
Ahimelech accused David of wrongdoing.
questions.correctAnswer: Ahimelech testified to David's faithfulness and his own innocence in the matter.
questions.explanation: In 1 Samuel 22:14-15, Ahimelech defends David's loyalty and his own integrity, teaching the importance of honesty and standing for truth even under pressure.

questions.question: How does Saul's order to kill the priests contrast with biblical principles of justice and mercy?
options: Saul ordered the death of innocent priests, showing injustice and lack of mercy.
Saul spared the priests and sought peaceful dialogue.
Saul punished only those proven guilty.
Saul showed mercy and forgiveness to all.
questions.correctAnswer: Saul ordered the death of innocent priests, showing injustice and lack of mercy.
questions.explanation: Verses 16-19 illustrate Saul's harsh and unjust actions against the priests, contrasting with biblical teachings to act justly, love mercy, and walk humbly with God.

questions.question: What does the escape of Abiathar teach about God's providence and protection in times of crisis?
options: Abiathar escaped and fled to David, showing God’s preservation of His servants.
Abiathar was killed with the rest of the priests.
Abiathar betrayed David to Saul.
Abiathar hid and never contacted David.
questions.correctAnswer: Abiathar escaped and fled to David, showing God’s preservation of His servants.
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:20-21 shows Abiathar escaping death and bringing news to David, demonstrating God's care and providence for His people during trials.

questions.question: A fellow believer feels guilty over unintended consequences of their actions. Based on David's words to Abiathar, what comfort can you offer?
options: David acknowledged the pain caused but encouraged Abiathar to stay with him for protection.
David condemned Abiathar for the deaths caused.
David told Abiathar to leave and face Saul alone.
David blamed Abiathar for his own troubles.
questions.correctAnswer: David acknowledged the pain caused but encouraged Abiathar to stay with him for protection.
questions.explanation: In 1 Samuel 22:22-23, David expresses sorrow over the deaths but offers reassurance and protection to Abiathar, teaching about compassion and support in times of guilt and fear.

questions.question: True or False: David became a leader by gathering only those who were wealthy and influential.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:2 states David gathered those in distress, debt, and discontent, not the wealthy or influential, showing leadership rooted in compassion and inclusivity.

questions.question: True or False: Saul's servants were willing to kill the priests of the LORD when Saul commanded it.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:17 explains that Saul's servants would not attack the priests, demonstrating reluctance to commit injustice even under the king's orders.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: David fled to the cave ______, where his family and others joined him for protection.
options: Adullam
Gibeah
Mizpeh
Ramah
questions.correctAnswer: Adullam
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:1 records that David fled to the cave Adullam, a place of refuge where his family and others gathered, illustrating God's provision of shelter during trials.

questions.question: How does David's leadership in 1 Samuel 22 teach about serving others amidst personal trials?
options: David took responsibility for those distressed and led them despite his own difficulties.
David focused only on his own safety and ignored others.
David sought to dominate others for personal gain.
David refused to associate with any followers.
questions.correctAnswer: David took responsibility for those distressed and led them despite his own difficulties.
questions.explanation: Verses 1-2 show David becoming a captain over those in distress, teaching servant leadership and caring for others even during personal hardship.

questions.question: What does Saul’s mistrust and rash judgment in this chapter warn believers about in their relationships?
options: Mistrust can lead to unjust actions and broken relationships.
Mistrust is necessary to protect oneself at all costs.
One should always act quickly without seeking understanding.
Suspicion is a sign of spiritual faithfulness.
questions.correctAnswer: Mistrust can lead to unjust actions and broken relationships.
questions.explanation: Saul’s baseless accusations and killing of priests (verses 7-19) warn that suspicion and lack of trust harm others and damage communities.

questions.question: How does Abiathar's loyalty to David demonstrate the value of faithfulness in difficult circumstances?
options: Abiathar fled danger to support and join David despite the risks.
Abiathar abandoned David to save himself.
Abiathar betrayed David to Saul for safety.
Abiathar remained silent and did not warn David.
questions.correctAnswer: Abiathar fled danger to support and join David despite the risks.
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:20-23 shows Abiathar risking safety to join David, exemplifying faithfulness and courage in times of trial.

questions.question: What does David’s handling of Abiathar’s news teach about responding to bad news with faith and wisdom?
options: David accepted the painful truth but encouraged trust and safety with him.
David reacted with anger and despair.
David ignored the news and pretended all was well.
David blamed Abiathar for bringing bad news.
questions.correctAnswer: David accepted the painful truth but encouraged trust and safety with him.
questions.explanation: In verses 22-23, David acknowledges the tragedy but comforts Abiathar and invites him to remain under his protection, showing faith and wise pastoral care.

hard.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 22 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Samuel Chapter 22.

questions.question: What was the primary reason people distressed, indebted, and discontented gathered around David at the cave of Adullam?
options: They sought a new king
They sought refuge and leadership
They wanted to rebel against Saul
They were sent by the Moabite king
questions.correctAnswer: They sought refuge and leadership
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:2 explains that those in distress, debt, and discontent gathered unto David, who then became a captain over them, indicating they sought refuge and leadership.

questions.question: To whom did David entrust his father and mother for protection, and what does this reveal about political alliances in the ancient Near East?
options: The king of Moab, showing reliance on regional kinship ties
The king of Ammon, showing David’s diplomatic reach
The Philistine lords, revealing David’s alliances with enemies
The priests of Nob, indicating religious sanctuaries as refuges
questions.correctAnswer: The king of Moab, showing reliance on regional kinship ties
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:3-4 shows David asked the king of Moab to protect his parents, reflecting the common ancient Near Eastern practice of seeking refuge through kinship or treaty relationships.

questions.question: What instruction did the prophet Gad give to David, and how does this reflect prophetic guidance in the Deuteronomistic history?
options: To leave the hold and go into Judah, emphasizing obedience to divine direction
To attack Saul’s forces, demonstrating militant prophecy
To flee to Egypt, foreshadowing later refuge narratives
To return to Saul and negotiate peace, showing prophetic mediation
questions.correctAnswer: To leave the hold and go into Judah, emphasizing obedience to divine direction
questions.explanation: According to 1 Samuel 22:5, Gad instructed David to depart the hold and enter Judah, illustrating the prophetic role of guiding kings according to God's will in the Deuteronomistic history.

questions.question: Where was Saul when he learned that David and his men were discovered, and what might the spear in his hand symbolize in this context?
options: In Gibeah under a tree in Ramah, symbolizing kingly authority and readiness for conflict
In Nob, symbolizing his religious authority
In the cave of Adullam, indicating pursuit of David
In Mizpeh of Moab, showing foreign alliances
questions.correctAnswer: In Gibeah under a tree in Ramah, symbolizing kingly authority and readiness for conflict
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:6 states Saul was in Gibeah under a tree in Ramah with his spear in hand, which likely symbolizes his royal power coupled with readiness for violence.

questions.question: What accusation did Saul make to the Benjamite servants regarding David, and what does this reveal about his leadership style?
options: That David conspired against him and none showed loyalty to Saul, revealing paranoia and authoritarian control
That David was a foreign spy, showing mistrust of outsiders
That David had stolen royal treasures, indicating concern over wealth
That David was unfit to lead, reflecting Saul’s insecurity
questions.correctAnswer: That David conspired against him and none showed loyalty to Saul, revealing paranoia and authoritarian control
questions.explanation: Verses 7-8 reveal Saul accusing the Benjamites of conspiring with David and failing to show him loyalty, highlighting Saul’s paranoid and authoritarian leadership.

questions.question: Who was Doeg the Edomite, and what role did he play in the events at Nob?
options: He was Saul’s servant who informed Saul about Ahimelech aiding David and later killed the priests, showing betrayal and violence
He was a Moabite king’s envoy who protected David’s family
He was a priest who refused to help David
He was David’s commander who led his followers
questions.correctAnswer: He was Saul’s servant who informed Saul about Ahimelech aiding David and later killed the priests, showing betrayal and violence
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:9-10 and 18 show Doeg as Saul’s servant who reported Ahimelech’s help to David and carried out the massacre of priests at Nob, demonstrating betrayal and ruthless execution of Saul’s orders.

questions.question: What items did Ahimelech the priest give to David, and what is their significance in the biblical narrative?
options: Bread and the sword of Goliath, symbolizing sustenance and divine victory legacy
A spear and shield, indicating military support
Holy oil and a prophecy, signifying anointment
A scroll of the law and a blessing, representing priestly authority
questions.correctAnswer: Bread and the sword of Goliath, symbolizing sustenance and divine victory legacy
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:10 records Ahimelech giving David bread and the sword of Goliath, symbolizing both physical sustenance and a connection to God’s past deliverance through David’s victory.

questions.question: How did Ahimelech defend himself against Saul’s accusations, and what does this reveal about priestly innocence and complicity?
options: He claimed ignorance and faithfulness to the king, highlighting the priests' non-involvement in political rebellion
He admitted conspiracy, showing collusion
He accused David of treason, deflecting blame
He fled before answering, indicating guilt
questions.correctAnswer: He claimed ignorance and faithfulness to the king, highlighting the priests' non-involvement in political rebellion
questions.explanation: In 1 Samuel 22:14-15, Ahimelech asserts he did not conspire and was faithful to Saul, emphasizing the priests’ innocence and separation from political intrigue.

questions.question: What was Saul’s order regarding the priests of Nob and what does this event foreshadow in Israel’s history?
options: To slay them all because they sided with David, foreshadowing priestly persecution and civil strife
To exile them to Moab, indicating political exile
To imprison them as traitors, highlighting royal justice
To send them as emissaries to David, foreshadowing reconciliation
questions.correctAnswer: To slay them all because they sided with David, foreshadowing priestly persecution and civil strife
questions.explanation: Verses 16-19 describe Saul ordering the killing of the priests and inhabitants of Nob, an event foreshadowing future conflicts between kings and priests.

questions.question: Who escaped the massacre at Nob and what role does he play subsequently in David’s story?
options: Abiathar, who fled and became David’s priest and advisor
Ahimelech, who later rebelled
Doeg, who betrayed David
Gad the prophet, who warned David
questions.correctAnswer: Abiathar, who fled and became David’s priest and advisor
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:20-23 recounts Abiathar escaping the slaughter and joining David, becoming his priest and spiritual counselor.

questions.question: How does David respond to Abiathar’s news of the priests’ death, and what does this reveal about David’s character?
options: He expresses sorrow and accepts responsibility, indicating humility and remorse
He vows revenge against Saul, showing vengeance
He blames Abiathar, demonstrating frustration
He ignores the news, focusing on survival
questions.correctAnswer: He expresses sorrow and accepts responsibility, indicating humility and remorse
questions.explanation: In 1 Samuel 22:22, David acknowledges that Doeg’s presence caused the deaths, showing his awareness of consequences and personal humility.

questions.question: Which literary device best describes the narrative structure involving David’s refuge, Saul’s paranoia, and the massacre at Nob?
options: Chiasm, highlighting the center event of divine justice and human failure
Parallelism, emphasizing repeated themes of refuge
Typology, foreshadowing the Messiah
Allegory, symbolizing spiritual warfare
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm, highlighting the center event of divine justice and human failure
questions.explanation: The narrative’s symmetrical structure—David’s refuge, Saul’s accusations, the massacre, and Abiathar’s escape—forms a chiasm emphasizing the theological tension between divine justice and human sin.

questions.question: How does the Hebrew meaning of “ephod” contribute to understanding the significance of those killed at Nob?
options: Ephod, a priestly garment, indicates those slain were priests serving in the sanctuary
Ephod means 'warrior’s armor', thus soldiers were killed
Ephod translates as 'king’s garment', indicating royal guards
Ephod refers to 'prophetic mantle', showing prophets were targeted
questions.correctAnswer: Ephod, a priestly garment, indicates those slain were priests serving in the sanctuary
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:18 mentions those wearing linen ephods, a priestly vestment, identifying the victims as priests and underscoring the sacrilegious nature of the massacre.

questions.question: True or False: Saul’s servants willingly carried out his command to kill the priests of the LORD.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:17 states Saul’s servants refused to kill the priests, showing reluctance to execute such a sacrilegious order.

questions.question: What theme introduced in 1 Samuel 22 is developed throughout the rest of the biblical narrative concerning David and Saul?
options: The conflict between God’s anointed king and human jealousy leading to persecution
The establishment of the monarchy’s supremacy over the priesthood
The alliance between David and foreign powers to secure the throne
The divine condemnation of all Edomites
questions.correctAnswer: The conflict between God’s anointed king and human jealousy leading to persecution
questions.explanation: This chapter highlights Saul’s jealousy and persecution of David, a theme that recurs throughout the narratives of their rivalry and the establishment of David’s kingship.

theological.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 22 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Samuel Chapter 22 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the primary reason David gathered about four hundred men to himself at the cave of Adullam?
options: They were distressed, in debt, and discontented
They were soldiers loyal to Saul
They were priests from Nob
They were Moabite allies
questions.correctAnswer: They were distressed, in debt, and discontented
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:2 states that those who were in distress, debt, and discontent gathered to David, illustrating God's providential care in using societal outcasts to form a community. This echoes themes in Luke 5:31 where Jesus calls sinners, and Romans 8:28 about God working through difficulties.

questions.question: To whom did David entrust his father and mother for protection while he was in hiding?
options: The king of Moab
The prophet Gad
The priests of Nob
The Benjamites
questions.correctAnswer: The king of Moab
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:3-4 shows David placing his parents under the care of the Moabite king, demonstrating his trust in God's providence through foreign rulers, reminiscent of Joseph's rise in Egypt (Genesis 39) and the protection of God's people in exile (Daniel 1).

questions.question: What prophetic instruction did Gad give to David while he was in the hold?
options: Abide not in the hold; depart and go into the land of Judah
Stay and fortify the hold
Attack Saul immediately
Seek refuge in Philistine territory
questions.correctAnswer: Abide not in the hold; depart and go into the land of Judah
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:5 records the prophet Gad commanding David to leave the hold and enter Judah, indicating divine guidance and the importance of obedience to God's timing, paralleling the call to Abraham to leave Ur (Genesis 12:1) and Israel's journey into the Promised Land.

questions.question: What was Saul's accusation against his servants, the Benjamites, upon discovering David's whereabouts?
options: They conspired against him and did not inform him about David
They supported Saul wholeheartedly
They were aiding the priests in Nob
They were conspiring with the Moabites
questions.correctAnswer: They conspired against him and did not inform him about David
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:7-8 reveals Saul's paranoia and distrust, accusing his own tribe of conspiracy and failure to inform him about David. This demonstrates human sinfulness and fear, consistent with Saul's tragic downfall (1 Samuel 15:24-30) and contrasts with God’s faithfulness (Psalm 37:28).

questions.question: Who informed Saul that David had come to Nob to see Ahimelech the priest?
options: Doeg the Edomite
Abiathar
Gad the prophet
One of Saul's servants
questions.correctAnswer: Doeg the Edomite
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:9 shows Doeg the Edomite reporting David’s visit to Nob, highlighting the role of betrayal and evil human agency in divine providence, akin to Judas’ betrayal in the New Testament (John 13:21-27), and the theme of deception in Scripture.

questions.question: What items did Ahimelech give to David that Saul considered as evidence of conspiracy?
options: Bread, the sword of Goliath, and inquired of God for him
Silver, armor, and horses
A scroll of the law and a trumpet
A crown and royal garments
questions.correctAnswer: Bread, the sword of Goliath, and inquired of God for him
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:10 and 13 indicate Ahimelech gave David these items and sought God's guidance for him, showing the priest’s faithful support. This contrasts Saul’s suspicion and highlights the biblical theme of seeking God's will (Exodus 28:30; Acts 1:24).

questions.question: How did Ahimelech respond to Saul's accusations of conspiring with David?
options: He denied knowing anything and emphasized David's faithfulness
He confessed to conspiring against Saul
He blamed Doeg the Edomite
He fled immediately
questions.correctAnswer: He denied knowing anything and emphasized David's faithfulness
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:14-15 shows Ahimelech defending himself and pointing to David’s loyalty, embodying integrity and innocence, consistent with biblical principles of justice (Proverbs 17:15) and the innocence of God’s servants (Acts 7:52).

questions.question: What was Saul's decree concerning Ahimelech and all his father's house?
options: They shall surely die
They shall be imprisoned
They shall be exiled
They shall be forgiven
questions.correctAnswer: They shall surely die
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:16 records Saul’s severe judgment, reflecting the tragic consequences of his jealousy and sin. This judgment contrasts with God's mercy (Psalm 103:8) and illustrates the danger of human vengeance (Romans 12:19).

questions.question: Who refused to execute the priests of the LORD when Saul ordered their death?
options: Saul’s servants
Doeg the Edomite
David’s men
The Benjamites
questions.correctAnswer: Saul’s servants
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:17 states that Saul’s servants would not harm the priests, showing conscience and reverence for holy persons, aligning with the biblical respect for God’s ministers (Hebrews 13:17) and the sanctity of life.

questions.question: Who actually carried out the killing of the priests at Nob?
options: Doeg the Edomite
Saul himself
David’s men
The Moabite king
questions.correctAnswer: Doeg the Edomite
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:18 records that Doeg executed the priests, demonstrating the destructive power of evil and betrayal, consistent with biblical warnings about wickedness (Psalm 7:14-16) and the consequences of sin (Romans 6:23).

questions.question: What was the extent of Doeg's destruction at Nob?
options: Men, women, children, animals—all were slain
Only the priests were killed
Only the men were killed
Only the temple was burned
questions.correctAnswer: Men, women, children, animals—all were slain
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:19 shows the thoroughness of Doeg’s massacre, underscoring the tragedy of innocent suffering and the brokenness of human sin, paralleling other biblical judgments (Joshua 6:21) and calling attention to God's justice (Isaiah 61:2).

questions.question: Who escaped the massacre at Nob and fled to David?
options: Abiathar, son of Ahimelech
Gad the prophet
Doeg the Edomite
Ahimelech himself
questions.correctAnswer: Abiathar, son of Ahimelech
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:20 records Abiathar’s escape, highlighting God’s preservation of a faithful remnant, a recurring biblical theme (Genesis 6:8-9; Revelation 12:17) and foreshadowing Abiathar’s later priestly role.

questions.question: What did David say to Abiathar regarding the death of his father's house?
options: He acknowledged that Doeg would tell Saul and felt responsible
He promised to avenge their deaths immediately
He denied any involvement in their deaths
He blamed Saul entirely
questions.correctAnswer: He acknowledged that Doeg would tell Saul and felt responsible
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:22 shows David expressing sorrow and responsibility for the tragic events, reflecting the biblical recognition of human suffering and sin’s consequences (Psalm 51:3-4; Romans 7:24).

questions.question: What assurance did David give to Abiathar upon his arrival?
options: Fear not; with me you shall be in safeguard
You will be king after me
You must flee to Moab for safety
You will be made captain of my men
questions.correctAnswer: Fear not; with me you shall be in safeguard
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:23 reveals David’s pastoral care and protection, reflecting the biblical motif of God as protector (Psalm 91:1-2) and the shepherd caring for his flock (John 10:11).

questions.question: What does David’s gathering of the distressed and discontented men teach about God’s kingdom?
options: God often uses marginalized people to fulfill His purposes
Only the wealthy and powerful are chosen
God rejects those in distress
God chooses only priests to lead
questions.correctAnswer: God often uses marginalized people to fulfill His purposes
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:2 shows David’s followers were distressed and discontented, illustrating God’s pattern of raising up the humble and outcasts (1 Corinthians 1:27-29; James 2:5), emphasizing grace and redemption.

questions.question: What theological lesson can be drawn from Saul’s refusal to act himself and sending Doeg to kill the priests?
options: Sin corrupts leadership and causes injustice
God approves all royal decisions
Violence is the best response to enemies
Priests are exempt from earthly justice
questions.correctAnswer: Sin corrupts leadership and causes injustice
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:17-18 illustrates Saul’s moral failure and the tragic consequences of his sinful jealousy, underscoring biblical warnings against corrupt leadership (Proverbs 29:2; Romans 1:18-32) and the call for righteous rule (Psalm 72:1-4).
